author: The Telegraph
title: Conference agenda
text: Find out more about Innovate in Brasil » **SUBJECT TO CHANGE** Date: Thursday 29 October 2015 Venue: Jumeirah Carlton Tower, One Cadogan Place, Knightsbridge, London, SW1X 9PY 10:00 Welcome address from the chairman PANEL DISCUSSION ONE Transforming innovation into commercial growth The need for businesses to adopt an agile and flexible approach is now pivotal in the dynamic and rapidly changing international business environment. This opening panel session will launch the discussion about how innovation in Brazil can generate new products, services and commercial gains. Panellists will identify the greatest innovation opportunities in Brazil and examine the reasons, including the size of the potential market, why the country has become a magnet for international innovation assets. The discussion will focus on how technology has been the catalyst in updating the approach that successful companies adopt on innovation. The significance of collaboration and partnerships between internal teams and external organisations will also be addressed. Infrastructure issues, including education, talent acquisition and the Brazilian government’s support framework for innovative businesses will also be touched on. Key themes will include: Creating an international and open approach to new business opportunities. Fostering innovation and creating world-class business initiatives. Building economic growth through partnerships and strategic alliances. Promoting a culture of entrepreneurship. Maximising potential from new technologies. Collaboration as a cornerstone to facilitating business growth. Leveraging core strengths and partnering externally to access new capabilities. PANEL DISCUSSION TWO Injecting growth into the Brazilian economy through innovation Apex-Brasil is spearheading the Brazilian government’s initiative to promote research and development. Innovation is now included in the Brazilian constitution in recognition of its fundamental role in building an agile and robust economy. In addition to improving access to university education, the Brazilian government is facilitating improved relationships between universities and businesses. Simultaneously, new government initiatives are promoting growth in the SME sector as well as investing in start-ups and entrepreneurship. Seed capital, venture capital and investment in education all demonstrate the government’s commitment to supporting innovation to increase Brazil’s GDP, job opportunities and long-term growth. Key themes will include: Providing a governmental framework to promote innovation. Cultivating a long-term approach to research and development. Examining the size of the Brazilian consumer market. Home-grown talent through Brazil’s investment in education. Government support – demonstrating what the Brazilian government can offer. Improving the regulatory framework for innovation. Planning for future generations of talent. PANEL DISCUSSION THREE Redefining innovation in the context of Brazil Successful commercial organisations are ushering in an era in which businesses look externally as well as internally for innovation capacity. Technology and ubiquitous access to ICT have changed the innovation paradigm. In this final discussion of the morning, companies who are active in Brazil will present case studies and examples of how they have successfully created a culture of innovation, creativity and growth. Speakers in this session will explore strategies for recruiting and retaining talented employees with a passion for innovation. Panellists will also discuss methods they have implemented to create a corporate culture of open innovation and collaboration. Forging strong links between universities, as well as creating productive commercial collaborative teams, are key pillars in ensuring that innovation creates effective and commercially viable products and services Key themes will include: Talent acquisition and retention as key components of successful innovation. Implementing an entrepreneurial mindset to boost business growth. Harnessing the democratisation of innovation. Responding to growing macroeconomic pressures impinging on the innovation ecosystem. Comparing the innovation climate in Brazil with other emerging markets and Brics. Agile innovation as a cultural shift within established organisations. Incorporating big data, IoT, cloud computing, HPC, fibre optics and micro-grids into new products. 12:00 Chairman’s closing remarks followed by networking brunch Innovate in Brasil is an invitation only conference. To make an inquiry please email Soosyan.Eng@telegraph.co.uk
